III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Supervision
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505
Section • (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
Description supervision:
1

• (c) Provide the youth with a telephone number to
contact the agency on a 24-hour, 7-days-a-week
basis.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth has been unable to get their Independent Living check and
has been unable to get in contact with anyone at the agency by
phone or in person.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 1/9/2025. She
reported receiving a text message from a former foster parent of
Youth A’s stating Youth A has not received her Independent Living
stipend check as Youth A has not been able to reach anyone at
the agency. Complainant stated Youth A went to the agency, but
no one was there.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed by video conferencing on
1/10/2025. She reported she was the assigned supervisor for the
case until the former foster care worker left 11/20/2024 at which
time she became the assigned worker. She stated the former
worker reached out to Youth A to let her know she was leaving.
Foster Care Worker reported having talked to Youth A the week
after Christmas and told her that her case was being transferred to
a local MDHHS. She stated Youth A did not tell her she had been
trying to reach anyone at the agency or that she visited the
agency when no one was there. Foster Care Worker stated if
Youth A visited the agency between Christmas and New Year,
there were days when there were no staff in the office.
Foster Care Worker stated Youth A’s check typically would have
arrived at the agency 12/30/2024 or 12/31/2024 but there was a
delay due to the holidays. The check arrived 1/2/2025 which was
a day Foster Care Worker was not working. Foster Care Worker
stated Youth A texted her 1/6/2025 asking when she could get her
check. They exchanged text messages and arranged for Foster
Care Worker to drop the check off to her that day. Foster Care
Worker stated, when she dropped off the check, Youth A did not
express any concerns other than wanting to find a new therapist.
Foster Care Worker reported Youth A’s next check will arrive next
week and she will reach out to Youth A to make sure she gets the
check. All her subsequent checks will be received by a local
MDHHS office.
A text message was sent to Youth A 1/14/2025 as Foster Care
Worker reported Youth A was in class and was more likely to
2

respond to texts. The text message explained there was an
investigation due to her not having received her check and not
being able to reach anyone at the agency and asked if she had
time to talk. Youth A responded with a text message stating she
has her check, and she had the wrong number listed for the
agency contact, but she is now all set.
DOCUMENT REVIEWED
Text Messages between Youth A and Foster Care Worker
1/6/2025 beginning with Youth A asking when she can get her
check and who her new worker will be. Foster Care Worker
responded she can drop off the check, followed by several texts
about where to meet and ending with a text from Youth A thanking
Foster Care Worker for bringing the check.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as Youth A had Foster Care
Worker’s contact information and was able to reach her to obtain
her stipend check.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted after a report that a youth in foster care had not received her Independent Living stipend check and was unable to contact the agency. The investigation found the youth did eventually receive her check by contacting her assigned worker, and the youth later stated she had initially used the wrong contact number for the agency. The report concludes no policy violation was established. Overall, while there was a lapse in communication and a delayed check delivery around the holidays, the agency's ultimate response and the youth's access to a worker cleared them of formal culpability.
